Items.Title: After Hours @ My Bras Basah with May Hui
Items.Content: The night is alive in Bras Basah! As you soak yourself in the spectacular sights and sounds of the Singapore Night Festival, join May Hui to explore the history of iconic buildings in Bras Basah, including the former St Joseph’s Institute, Cathedral of the Good Shepherd and National Museum of Singapore. Uncover stories of Charlie Chaplin and Michael Jackson’s stays in Raffles Hotel. Walk through Bras Basah Complex and hear the memories and stories of the old bookshops there.

Items.Title: An Ocean Without The Anchor by Speak Cryptic
Items.Content:
An Ocean Without the Anchor is inspired by the lighthouse, a sturdy structure synonymous with being a beacon of hope shining in the darkness. A guiding light for those lost at sea, the lighthouse gives a sense of comfort to seamen leaving and returning home. Aptly located at the entrance of Raffles City – which would have then been along the Singapore shoreline before land reclamation took place in 1822 – this installation is a nod to the Bugis people and their rich history as seafarers.

Conveying the value of bergotong-royong (Malay for cooperation), the tower comprises five figures sitting stacked on one another's shoulders. At the top is the roof of a traditional kampung house, signifying shelter and safety as our community slowly transitions into “the new normal”.

Creating an atmospheric auditory experience is an accompanying soundtrack featuring the sounds of the sea and kampung life drawn from SoundScapeSG and the National Archives of Singapore.

This programme is co-presented by the National Heritage Board (NHB) and National Library Board (NLB) as part of Singapore Night Festival and Curiocity, an NLB initiative, to discover hidden stories and facets of Singapore’s past from the National Library and the National Archives of Singapore collections. #SGStoryTellers

About Speak Cryptic
Farizwan Fajari, professionally known as Speak Cryptic, is a Singaporean artist. Endless manifestations of the self are a feature of his work, depicting identity in the form of texts and phrases extracted from punk lyrics and intricate patterns and figures. His drawings, paintings and installations stem from inquiries into ancestral migration, ethnic dislocation, gentrification and alternative subcultures. Speak Cryptic has participated in exhibitions such as the Koganecho Art Bazaar (Yokohama, Japan, 2018), the 1st Kuala Lumpur Biennale (2017), Secret Archipelago (Paris, France, 2015), the Singapore Biennale (2013) and Future Proof (Singapore, 2012).
Items.ImageAlt: An Ocean Without The Anchor by Speak Cryptic

Items.Title: Battlebox Night Entry
Items.Content:
Explore the top secret Battlebox where Lieutenant-General Percival and his senior officers directed the Battle for Singapore in World War II. Venture into this authentic underground command centre 9 metres underground with an expert guide to lead the way.

Discover the labyrinth of rooms and corridors and view authentic wartime artefacts. Watch the war unfold on land and on sea, follow the battles in the air, and discover the tension and drama behind the decision to surrender the much-vaunted ‘Singapore Fortress’ on 15 February 1942.

Please purchase tickets on-site at the Battlebox Visitor Centre

Venue:
Battlebox
2 Cox Terrace, Singapore 179622 (Fort Canning Park)

Items.Title: Cathay Hotel: The Curse Of The Missing Red Shoe by Vertical Submarine
Items.Content:
Image courtesy of Vertical Submarine

 

Tickets for Cathay Hotel on Klook are all sold out! Please make your purchases via the Changi Recommends link below.

 

Venue: Cathay Green

Dates: 19, 20, 24, 25, 26 & 27 Aug

Time:  7.30pm and 8.45pm, with additional show at 10pm on Fridays and Saturdays

Duration: 45 mins

Admission:

  • $33 per participant
  • [Spark Connections Exclusive] $16.50 per participant + complimentary cocktail (via Spark Connections)
  • *All prices stated are inclusive of GST and booking fee

Watch the past come to life at Cathay Hotel: The Curse of the Missing Red Shoe, an immersive theatre performance taking place within a re-creation of the historical Cathay complex. The detective story begins at a hotel where a mysterious curse from more than 60 years ago led to the separation of two lovers and changed the ending of the cinderellaesque Cathay film Lion City (1960), which inspires this production. In this anti-fairytale, we encounter the reappearance of iconic characters from the Cathay universe such as Mat Bond, Orang Minyak, Pontianak, Mambo Girl and ASP Latiff. Entering into a surreal version of old Singapore, where memories are confused with cinematic imaginations, everyone helping with the investigation could be a suspect.

 

This is a Vertical Submarine production written and created by Justin Loke. The performance is directed by Jeremiah Choy and features local actors such as Rebekah Sangeetha Dorai, Munah Bagharib, Rizman Putra, Xavier Kang and Andrew Marko. 

Cathay Hotel Programme Booklet available here.

Content warning: a scene in this production contains a brief mention of pregnancy loss and blood.

 

About Vertical Submarine

Vertical Submarine by Justin Loke and Fiona Koh is a local art collective whose cross-disciplinary projects, which incorporate theatre and curation, explore methods of storytelling and narrative via words and images. The group has received accolades such as The President's Young Talents Award (Singapore, 2009), The Celeste Prize (New York, 2011), and Finalist for Sovereign Asian Art Prize (Hong Kong, 2015). Their widely acclaimed art installations, which includes The Garden of Forking Paths / Mirror Room (2010) and John Martin: Butcher or Surgeon (2015) have travelled to Barcelona, Beijing, Hong Kong, London, Mexico City and Taipei.

 

A Spark Connections Special
Enjoy up to 50% OFF and a bespoke cocktail when you book via Spark Connections.
Sign up here to claim exclusive perks (including $100 FREE credits) to offset your ticket price.

Items.Title: Celebration of Life+Style by Justin Lee
Items.Content:
Celebration of Life+Style is a sculptural installation presented as a metaphor to investigate the prevailing social and cultural norms in Singapore, and is inspired by Stamford Arts Centre, a multidisciplinary arts centre with a focus on Traditional Arts. By juxtaposing traditional eastern characters with modern elements, the motifs are a tongue-in-cheek representation of how we manoeuvre within our modern day relationships in different arenas such as the arts, sports, entertainment, social media and the digital realm, inviting viewers to reflect on the impact of technology on our daily lives.

About Justin Lee
Justin Lee is a Singaporean visual artist and designer. As one of Singapore’s foremost pop artists, whose design projects reflect a fine sense of contemporary design flavoured with an essence of Singapore traditions, Justin’s work deserves accolades as both a designer and artist. His approach to design is executed with current graphic fundamentals yet reflecting traditional techniques, such as his ongoing series based on paper-cutting and Chinese woodblock printing styles.

Venue
Frangipani garden beside Stamford Arts Centre

Items.Title: Singapore Night Festival @ Saints Peter and Paul
Items.Content:
Welcome to our church! Learn about the meanings and significance behind Christian symbols and statues, and see up close what hidden treasures the Church guards.

Discover more about the rich history of the church with our friendly guides or pick up a self-guide and explore the church on your own.

Have a knack for all things beautiful? Join us as we explore the relationship between art and faith. Ever wondered why a priest chose to be a priest, or how do religious brothers live? Come ask to your hearts content everything you wondered about how Catholics live their lives!

Items.Title: City of Books by Fish Jaafar
Items.Content:
Titled after the popular nickname of Bras Basah Complex, City of Books is a large-scale anamorphic pavement mural that features books flying into a void through a one-point 2D plane perspective.

The flight of books – from old fictional novels to the nostalgic 10-year series assessment books – symbolises the transition from printed to digital media. Bras Basah Complex remains a communal retail space for books and art despite the change in literary consumption trend. Through the traditional medium of painting and limited use of digital aids, the artist aims to create a sense of wonderment for the visitors, while paying tribute to the heritage and history of Bras Basah Complex as a retail mecca of books.
 
About Fish Jaafar
Fish Jaafar, a Singaporean visual artist, is known for producing large-scale works with conceptual accessibility and relevance to the local community. He believes that narratives are most honest when expressed figuratively within a traditional 2D plane. Aside from painting, his studio produces a variety of works from large 3D theming fabrication works in amusement parks and malls, to smaller works such as 3D printed miniature figurines.
Items.ImageAlt: City of Books by Fish Jaafar

Items.Title: Code of Silence (Fort Canning Escape Game)
Items.Content:
An Escape Game event in a real World War II Bunker in the Battlebox at Fort Canning Park

February 1942. The commanders of Malaya Command are deep in discussions in Battlebox over the imminent fall of Singapore and they are running out of time. You have been tasked to activate a top-secret protocol, which is to send a code word to the secret agents of Force 136 to escape before it is too late. The code word has been encrypted and the Japanese are approaching soon. The future of the resistance lies in your hands.

Venue:
Battlebox
2 Cox Terrace, Singapore 179622 (Fort Canning Park)

Items.Title: Discoloo Centre by P7:1SMA
Items.Content:
Courtesy of P7:1SMA

Feel the city breakin’ and everybody shakin’
And we’re stayin’ alive
-Bee Gees

As disco-goers move through Waterloo centre, get an insider glimpse of its podium-tower building typology paired with historical anecdotes of disco fever. This roving performance is a chance to relive the diverse rhythms and relationships that once existed in our precinct’s nightlife.

About Waterloo Centre
Waterloo Centre is a cluster of HDB flats built in the podium-tower building typology. It was built in 1978 at the heart of the Bras Basah.Bugis precinct. This architecture is a symbol of urban intensifications across Singapore. Its 4-storey commercial podium was known as the place to go for affordable spare parts. It also housed residents and businesses that were displaced due to redevelopment in the vicinity.

About Disco
Disco was more than just a genre of music, it was a cultural phenomenon as it created fashion, clubs and lifestyle. Among the discos that cropped up in the precinct was ‘The Kelong’. This restaurant, bar and nightclub in the Cathay had an authentic fishing stake setting. Due to a crackdown on dancing and entertainment spots, which were believed to influence drug abuse, ‘The Kelong’ was closed. Soon, in the mid-1970s, disco clubs featuring live bands and dancing seemed a thing of the past.

Meeting Point: In front of SPACOS located at Waterloo Centre. 
The programme is free with walk-in registration on site at the meeting point 30 minutes before each show. Limited to 30 participants per show on a first come first serve basis. 

About P7:1SMA
P7:1SMA (pronounced as Prisma) is a dance performance company that embodies traditional and contemporary practices. The group’s body of work advocates the relevance of culture across communities. P7:1SMA radically shifts the perspective of Malay and dance through intimate and innovative performance experiences.

Items.Title: Explore SG Night Fest with Trishaw Uncle
Items.Content: Explore the Bras Basah.Bugis (BBB) precinct with Trishaw Uncle in this year's edition of Singapore Night Festival! Be enchanted by the festival’s artwork installations and learn about the cultural history of Bras Basah.Bugis (BBB) precinct, as we ride through some of Singapore’s iconic buildings such as Raffles Hotel, Armenian Church and Oxford Hotel.

Items.Title: Fēcundus by Twardzik Ching Chor Leng
Items.Content:
Play and interact with these inflatables representing rice kernels, rings and rice plant, to squeeze and combine the shapes to form other organic sculptures based on your own imagination. Inspired by the meaning of “Bras Basah” or beras basa, which means “wet rice”, Fēcundus creates a playground of larger-than-life inflatable structures for visitors to come together to build a rice plant or construct their own creations. The organic shapes, reminiscent of rice kernels, can be combined to resemble seeds, pods and buds, plants growing and bustling into life on an artificial lawn. The work brings people together through play, symbolising the rebirthing of the area from a fishing village to an entrepot, from an island to a nation, from isolation to the bustling city and into the future.

About Twardzik Ching Chor Leng
Twardzik Ching Chor Leng has exhibited internationally, at the Jakarta Biennale #14, Indonesia, Ahrengsburg, Germany, Tokyo, Japan, and Calgary and Regina in Canada. In Singapore, public commissions of Chor Leng’s works include the Istana, the Esplanade, the Singapore Art Show, Singapore Management University, National Institute of Education, National Museum of Singapore and Singapore Art Museum. Her recent commissions include the National Gallery Singapore (2015), Google Asia Pacific office (2017), Roppongi Art Night, Tokyo, Japan (2018), Public Art commission by the National Arts Council in commemoration of the Singapore Bicentennial (2019/20), and the Land Transport Authority for the Thomson Line MRT station (2022).
Items.ImageAlt: Fēcundus by Twardzik Ching Chor Leng

Items.Title: Glitches of You by Amanda Tan
Items.Content:
Glitches of You explores the notion of a multicultural modern identity in a dance of glitch art and fractured pixels, drawing from the artist’s own personal history and experience, through her identity as product of mixed bloodlines and therefore of dual cultures.

 

Paired with soundscapes composed by local musician Intriguant, the projection embraces the Stamford Court clock tower and the hustle-bustle of a busy intersection. By manipulating archival material and the artist’s self-filmed footage in the Bras Basah.Bugis (BBB) district, the artwork takes the viewer on a visual journey through a fragmented landscape where the past meets the present.

 

About Amanda Tan (Empyreal)

Amanda Tan (Empyreal) is a filmmaker, director, visual designer, writer and artist. Specialising in visual prose, music and movement, she strives to create work that speaks to the state of human emotion through the experimental moving image. Tan’s music videos and short films have been screened and nominated for awards at various film festivals, including the Bucharest ShortCut Cinefest, Berlin Short Film Festival, NYC Indie Film Awards, and Singapore Short Film Festival. She has shown her video installation pieces all over the world from Moscow to Yangon, Delhi, Bangkok and Singapore.
Items.ImageAlt: Glitches Of You by Amanda Tan

Items.Title: Singapore Night Festival @ GRiD
Items.Content:
Echoing this year’s theme of “Rebirth”, GR.iD – (a rebirth from PoMo), is now more than a space to shop or dine at. This is go-to space for the public and community to be connected, to indulge and to be energised with GR.iD's physical attributes (with many content and experience worthy spots) including its maiden participation in Singapore Night Festival 2022. GR.iD showcases its owner-operated unique offerings and offbeat experiences for the first time including the neon installations, featuring sustainable materials given new life and interactive music beats. Check out these instagrammable installations at GR.iD, especially at the Atrium and Social staircase and some of their unique food & beverages promotions till midnight!

Try our special Singapore Night Festival drink, Midnight Blues, by Super Coco, or recharge and 'refuel' at Kamikaze Asian Tapas Bar, GR.iD's alfresco rooftop dining till late, and explore the many more F&B promotions offered by GR.iD!

Items.Title: Thanksgiving Stories and Songs @ Queen Street
Items.Content:
Hear stories and songs from an unbroken community with more than 100 years of history, that has witnessed the growth of our nation and transformation of this neighbourhood, and continues to exist today to testify to the power of love, hope and redemption.

True to our name 感恩, perhaps there has there has never been a better time for thanksgiving. May stories not only be heard, but also shared. Come join us for an elevating time of laughter, tears and music.

Languages used in this programme include English, Mandarin, Hokkien and Cantonese. 

Venue:
Kum Yan Methodist Church, 1 Queen St, Singapore 188534

Items.Title: latent (BBB edition) by Chok Si Xuan
Items.Content:
Exploring biological interfaces in nature, latent (BBB edition) places organic botanical forms imitating the act of breathing throughout the green space of the Armenian Apostolic Church. Highlighting the potential and energy of the precinct, the poetic movements of the mechanical flowers brings life and rhythm to the seemingly solemn location. The work reflects upon the qualities of patience and resilience rooted in the history of the Armenian community and its oldest Church in Singapore.

Identify the motif of our national flower, Vanda Miss Joaquim, the first orchid hybrid bred by Singaporean Armenian Agnes Joaqium. As an active member of the Armenian Church, her tombstone lies in ‘The Memorial Garden to the Armenians’ in the churchyard. Alluding to its quiet strength and significance, latent (BBB edition) acknowledges the extensive roots the Armenian community have in Singapore.

About Chok Si Xuan
Chok Si Xuan is an installation based artist whose practice primarily investigates material systems - as embodiments of connections or relationships and attempts to mimic disrupting technologies with bodily gestures. Interested in cybernetics and exploration of physicality through systems, she is curious about how culture, material and form shapes the way we understand each other. Her installation based work constructs a visual language using varied physical mediums and kinetic elements through electronics, motors, 3D printing and sensors.
Items.ImageAlt: latent (BBB edition) by Chok Si Xuan

Items.Title: Madeleine by Lueur
Items.Content:
Ever wondered what are the roots and identity of the Bras Basah.Bugis precinct? Drawing inspiration from the themes of memory and nostalgia, Madeleine is a visual journey that takes the viewer through historical landmarks and cultural milestones unique to the BBB precinct. Presented in a vibrant pop art style, the animated projection depicts a curious hornbill’s flight through the precinct’s history, arts, spaces, residences and iconic religious buildings.

About Lueur
Looking to add a hint of magic and mystery to the BBB precinct is Lueur, a collective formed by Chan Yeng Huei Sherlene, Chan Yun Qi, Elyza Tan, Han En Yu and Siti Fairos Masyirah. As students from the School of Film & Media Studies’ (Ngee Ann Polytechnic) Diploma in Media Post-Production, their individual passion for the arts and media production is informed by a diverse mix of creative and technical production skill-sets.

Items.Title: Midnight Show at the Capitol by MOJOKO
Items.Content:
Take a trip down memory lane with this hyper-colourful visual treat. Remixing images from the collections of the National Archives of Singapore and National Library, visual artist MOJOKO highlights Singapore’s cinemas of times past. Inspired by the cultural importance and rich visual history of Capitol Theatre and Cathay Picture House, MOJOKO brings a contemporary twist to the classic movie posters that were once commonplace in the area. A moving artwork of epic proportions, Midnight Show at the Capitol lights up the walls of the Bras Basah.Bugis precinct in a captivating way.

This programme is co-presented by the National Heritage Board (NHB) and National Library Board (NLB) as part of Singapore Night Festival and Curiocity, an NLB initiative, to discover hidden stories and facets of Singapore’s past from the National Library and the National Archives of Singapore collections. #SGStoryTellers

About MOJOKO
If you are not already familiar with his work, Singapore-based MOJOKO is best described as a Pop Art mash-up artist and collage specialist. Often inspired by Singapore’s culture and the energy of living in Southeast Asia, his artworks explore the clashing of cultures, virtual vs. reality, old vs. new, east vs. west. As the creative director of EYEYAH! Magazine, he hopes to share this creativity to inspire the next generation of artists.
Items.ImageAlt: Midnight Show at the Capitol by MOJOKO

Items.Title: Buwan Art Collective
Items.Content:
Fragile! Once Broken, considered Broke is a live performance-based art that uses repetitive bodily movements and written
texts, and explores the 'protests' of three young adults confined in a site-specific space.

To grapple with the underlying issue of the self, and in reference to the marketing policy of ‘Once broken, considered sold', this performance hopes to become a cathartic visual experience as it explores issues concerning mental health from people of all ages. The materials which include brown paper bags, a mannequin with red thread, and a honeycomb paper wrap, attempt to communicate with our bodies, responding to an object's tension and pressure.

NAFA Campus 1 - Open Window Class Showcase

Items.Title: Archives Invites: Dr Caroline Chia – Telling a Tale about Hainanese Rod Puppetry
Items.Content:
Have you ever heard or seen Hainanese rod puppets? Did you know that there was a Hainanese enclave in Bugis where these puppet shows were once staged? Drawing upon archival sources and more than a decade of research, Dr. Caroline Chia shares the untold stories of Hainanese rod puppetry that has existed in Singapore for nearly a century.

National Archives of Singapore, Oldham Theatre, Level 3
1 Canning Rise, Singapore 179868

About the speaker
Dr. Caroline Chia has spent about 15 years researching on traditional Chinese theatre, including opera and puppetry. Despite its presence in Singapore for close to a century, little is known about traditional Chinese puppetry and Caroline believes there is great urgency to document and heighten awareness of this art before it disappears.

Items.Title: Cityscapes of Yesteryear: Screening and Music Performance
Items.Content:
Curious about how Singapore’s city centre looked like in the 1950s and 60s? Join us for a special screening of rare colour footage featuring Singapore’s streets and landmarks, and enjoy live music performed by M’Ode Wind Quintet, known for their unique yet flexible sound.

National Archives of Singapore, Atrium, Level 3
1 Canning Rise, Singapore 179868

Items.Title: Curiocity Encounters: Singapore Night Festival 2022
Items.Content:
Experience Singapore’s familiar spaces and venues in fresh ways at this year’s Singapore Night Festival! Visit Curiocity Encounters and unearth old and new stories of the Bras Basah.Bugis precinct through a series of creative installations, programmes, tours and digital content.

Curiocity Encounters: Singapore Night Festival 2022 draws on the Singapore collections from the National Library Board and its partners, enabling them to be accessed outside of the libraries and archives in innovative ways. Presented in varied formats both in-person and online, we invite you to be inspired, to discover, learn and engage with our island’s stories.

#CuriocitySG #LAB25 #SGStoryTellers

Items.Title: School Bells and Hallways: Memories of Former School Buildings
Items.Content:
Did you know that the National Archives of Singapore (NAS) sits on the site that was once Anglo-Chinese School (Primary)? Do you know which other schools used to be located in the Bras Basah.Bugis precinct? Join heritage guide Jerome Lim as he takes you on a journey to discover the interesting tales held at NAS, as well as former school buildings in the neighbourhood.

Meeting point:
Archives Reading Room, Level 2
National Archives,
1 Canning Rise, Singapore 179868

About Jerome Lim
Jerome Lim is the author of the award-winning blog The Long and Winding Road, where he documents the ever-evolving country of his birth through words and photographs. Jerome is a regular contributor to the heritage scene, organising walks of discovery to lesser-known sides of Singapore, through collaborations with various agencies such as the Singapore Land Authority and the National Heritage Board. He has also curated heritage exhibitions and trails, including The Italian Connection for the Fullerton Building’s 89th anniversary

Items.Title: NLB  Traditional Puppetry Performance by San Chun Long
Items.Content:
When was the last time you saw a live Chinese puppetry performance? Once common sights at temples and in the heartlands of Singapore, they are now rarely seen. Experience this artform as Hainanese rod puppet troupe, San Chun Long, performs this traditional craft with miniature puppets dressed in traditional Chinese opera costumes.

National Archives of Singapore, Stairway, Level 1
1 Canning Rise, Singapore 179868

About the troupe
Established in 1947, San Chun Long is the oldest and last surviving Hainanese puppet troupe in Singapore. It gained a reputation in Southeast Asia for furthering the artform especially during the mid-20th century.

Items.Title: NOCTURNE: Conversations with Waterloo by Nhawfal Juma'at
Items.Content:
What gives a place significance? What creates space for new memories, ideas and imagination? The answer is what binds us together. NOCTURNE: Conversations with Waterloo presents two sculptures captured in a transient moment when a conversation is midway, overheard in a communal space like the coffeeshop; where possibilities of the discussion are limitless. Playing on humankind’s intrinsic nature to create and engage in conversation, the artwork encapsulates the feeling one gets when accidentally overhearing a snippet of conversation while enroute to a destination, and finding what was said oddly relatable even if just for a moment. The concept of conversation, a phenomenon that allows us to understand, contemplate and traverse the passage of time, is likened to nocturnes lighting up in our minds  growing and expanding, similar to how plants respond to the sun in constant reincarnation and rebirth.

 

About Nhawfal Juma'at

Nhawfal Juma'at is a Singapore-based artist whose conceptually-driven artworks translate across several mediums. His works directly respond to the surrounding environment and utilise his everyday experiences as a starting point. Often these are framed instances that go unnoticed in their original context, where meaning and interpretation become multifaceted in the face of mundane deconstruction. Juma'at received his Bachelor of Arts in Fine Art with Honours from Loughborough University in partnership with Nanyang Academy of Fine Arts. He has exhibited extensively in Singapore in recent years and also embarked on a curatorial role across several exhibitions.
Items.ImageAlt: NOCTURNE_ Conversations with Waterloo by Nhawfal Juma'at

Items.Title: Objectifs Cinema: Now Showing
Items.Content:
Objectifs Cinema: Now Showing is a celebration of the richness and diversity of Southeast Asian short films.

It is an exhibition that hopes to gather film lovers of all backgrounds through screenings, talks, sharing sessions, and a film memorabilia showcase. It aims to set the stage for deeper discussions and a broader understanding of short films in the region.

Click the link below to learn more about the various films, or register for panel discussions at the Objectifs Chapel Gallery!

Venue:
 Objectifs Chapel Gallery
155 Middle Rd, Singapore 188977

Items.Title: Paddy Fields by FARM
Items.Content:
Paddy Fields recalls the forgotten practice of drying cultivated rice along the banks of Sungei Brass Bassa (now Stamford Canal) in the early 19th-century. The area was close to the paddy fields that used to be located opposite today’s KK Women’s and Children’s Hospital. South Asian washermen and women also laundered clothes there, laying them out to dry on an adjacent open space. Using a palette of humble materials, this installation seeks to evoke the sentiments reminiscent of these activities from a bygone era.

Follow the text running along the clusters of rice paddy to trace the story of Bras Basah (which means “wet rice” in Malay), from its agricultural roots to its history of redevelopment over the years. These quotes are extracted from poems (including “Bras Basah 1953” by Singapore poet Edwin Thumboo) and articles found in the collections of the National Archives of Singapore and National Library. 

This programme is co-presented by the National Heritage Board (NHB) and National Library Board (NLB) as part of Singapore Night Festival and Curiocity, an NLB initiative, to discover hidden stories and facets of Singapore’s past from the National Library and the National Archives of Singapore collections. #SGStoryTellers

About FARM
Based in Singapore, FARM is a cross-disciplinary company spanning design, architecture, arts and research. The company seeks to cultivate a culture of imagination, endeavouring to share the delight and joyful creativity that underpins all human action. Since 2005, FARM has worked on community projects which promote the arts and has organised national public art competitions and events. In 2007, FARM established its cross-disciplinary design arm, and has since embarked on diverse collaborations with artists and designers. These include architecture and interior design, product design and merchandising, graphic design and branding, art installation and sculpture, exhibition design and curatorial work.

Items.Title: PALIMPSEST by William Chan and Brandon Tay
Items.Content:
Artists’ impression, courtesy of William Chan and Brandon Tay

Drawing inspiration from the communities, buildings, architecture and art that once was on Armenian Street, PALIMPSEST is a poetic expression of the artists’ contemporary take into the history and evolution of the now pedestrianised street. This collaborative work by William Chan and Brandon Tay combines digital images, text and sound that celebrates the pulsating energy of Armenian Street – a site steeped in discoveries, experimentation, and discourse.
 
Comparing the evolution of Armenian Street to a palimpsest – a medieval wax tablet or parchment from which writing has been partially or completely erased to make space for another text, these multiple translucent screens can be seen as a series of connections, presenting the Street as a palimpsest both literally and metaphorically, inscribed with layers of meaning of “here and then” and “then and now”. Meanwhile, the deconstructed cube is a reference and critique to the “white cube” paradigm which alludes to the move away from the traditional confines of the museum and art gallery spaces.

About William Chan
Founder of TMRRW, a multidisciplinary design and motion studio based in Singapore, William Chan is an artist, multi-award winning designer, creative director and film/tvc director. His portfolio Includes MTV, Nike, Singapore Tourism Board, Tiktok, HBO and Meta. Additionally, he is a juror for the Creative Circle Awards and PromaxBDA award.

About Brandon Tay
Brandon Tay is a Singaporean artist working between the fields of installation and the moving image. His projects are concerned with how agency is defined in culture, technology, and politics. Drawing parallels between these fields, he creates CGI films and projection-mapping installations that depict how similar principles in these disparate domains inform each other.

Items.Title: Project Solitude
Items.Content:
This immersive installation invites visitors to slow down in today’s fast-paced society and experience moments of solitude. Through the showcase, we hope viewers are able to reconnect with their sense of self and the things they may overlook in their daily lives.

Duration: 17 mins

Gallery Theatre, Basement Level, National Museum of Singapore

Project Solitude was designed in 2021 by students from the Nanyang Academy of Fine Arts (NAFA) and National University of Singapore, as part of a special project organised by NAFA.
Items.Time: 9 and 20 Aug, 26 and 27 Aug: 5pm – 12am. On other days: 2pm – 6pm

Items.Title: Yesterday Once More: Queen Street by Inch Chua & Tim De Cotta
Items.Content:
Courtesy of Inch Chua, Euphoria Pole and Tim De Cotta

Travel through time over the history of Queen Street as Yesterday Once More: Queen Street enthralls audiences with song and sonic storytelling. The stories of people who live(d) on Queen Street – the dhobies, Auntie Cecilia who lived through the Japanese occupation, a young mother who sold noodles come rain or shine, a bride who waited for her groom to turn up, and a seasoned pole dancer – will unfold before your eyes and spark imagination of the years from the 1880s to the present day. The roving theatre performance is accompanied by high-definition audio on the Cinewav mobile app, featuring soundtracks composed by Inch Chua, original music by Tim De Cotta and performances by Euphoria Pole & Aerial Studio, Chowk Productions and CJ Bubble Girl.

 
Check out the Artist Line-up and Bios here!

Meeting Point: Singapore Management University (SMU) Campus Green.

About Inch Chua

Born in Singapore, educated in fine arts, and inducted into the music industry in Los Angeles, Inch Chua has made a career as an international award-winning recording and performing artist. Her passion for the arts, wild places, and technology has led her to play at numerous festivals around the world and to experiment in a variety of art forms. Chua is a recipient of the National Youth Award in 2018 for her contributions in the arts and was recently awarded Best Sound at the 2020 LIFE! Theatre Awards for her multisensory theatrical music production in 'Til The End Of The World, We'll Meet In No Man's Land.

 

About Tim De Cotta

Tim De Cotta is a vocalist, bassist, songwriter and producer who draws influences from R&B and hiphop. Having played in various bands, Tim’s diverse music career constantly pushes the boundaries in writing, producing, sessionist playing, and recording. Tim also worked with various arts, commercial and national agencies since 2015, such as the National Arts Council, Singapore Tourism Board, Temasek Holdings, Disney and Garena to bolster and grow the Singapore music and creative scene and presence in the commercial sector.

The programme is free with no registration required, please download the Cinewav mobile app on your device before the start of the programme. Do kindly bring along your own earphones to listen to the audio on the Cinewav mobile app.
Items.ImageAlt: Queen Street Yesterday Once More by-Inch-Chua-and-Tim-De-Cotta

Venue.Value: Various locations along Queen Street, starting point at SMU Campus Green

Items.Title: A Night to Remember by SCWO
Items.Content:
For the first time, SCWO is participating in the Singapore Night Festival! Join us for a beautiful night to remember as we celebrate the women of yesterday, today and tomorrow. 

The areas of Bras Basah and Bugis will be an array of lights. Come and light up the night with us through our various activities:

The “SINGAPORE WOMEN’S HALL OF FAME” Exhibition which seeks to celebrate the achievements of women in Singapore, and to document and share the stories of these remarkable women.

“THE LIVES OF WOMEN: What will life be like for women in Singapore in 2050?” Exhibition which looks at key issues and trends affecting women in Singapore today and pose questions about what the situation might be like in 2050.

Art workshops, Henna drawing, Games (fun for children!)

So, bring your family and friends down for a night of fun & learning and you may stand a chance to walk away with some prizes too!
 
About SCWO
The Singapore Council of Women's Organisations (SCWO) was established in 1980 as the national coordinating body of women's organisations in Singapore. SCWO has more than 60 member organisations, representing over 600,000 women, and it serves to unite them to work toward the ideals of 'Equal Space, Equal Voice and Equal Worth' for women in Singapore.

Equal Space: Women should feel safe wherever they are, free to live their lives as they choose without any danger of discrimination, harassment, sexual assault, and violence.

Equal Voice: Women should be equally represented in political, corporate, and community leadership. Policymaking will benefit from the perspectives they bring to the discussions and decisions.

Equal Worth: Women should be fully recognised and valued for their contributions to society, family, and the workplace, where there should be no gender wage gap for work of equal value.

Venue:
Singapore Council of Women’s Organisations
96 Waterloo Street, 187967

Items.Title: A Night to Remember by SCWO
Items.Content:
For the first time, SCWO is participating in the Singapore Night Festival! Join us for a beautiful night to remember as we celebrate the women of yesterday, today and tomorrow. 

The areas of Bras Basah and Bugis will be an array of lights. Come and light up the night with us through our various activities:

The “SINGAPORE WOMEN’S HALL OF FAME” Exhibition which seeks to celebrate the achievements of women in Singapore, and to document and share the stories of these remarkable women.

“THE LIVES OF WOMEN: What will life be like for women in Singapore in 2050?” Exhibition which looks at key issues and trends affecting women in Singapore today and pose questions about what the situation might be like in 2050.

Art workshops, Henna drawing, Games (fun for children!)

So, bring your family and friends down for a night of fun & learning and you may stand a chance to walk away with some prizes too!

Venue:

96 Waterloo Street, 187967

Items.Title: Heritage Night Walk: Walking in the Footsteps of our Foremothers
Items.Content:
Immerse yourself in Singapore’s heritage and the impact that women have had on the nation’s development. These walks in and around the city centre take you by the buildings and areas associated with some of the women in the Singapore Women’s Hall of Fame. Expert guides offer fascinating information about the women, their achievements and their legacy.

Walking in the Footsteps of our Foremothers take about 1.5 hours around the Bras Basah Bugis Precinct.

Highlights:
The rich history of each landmark along the route;
How the women highlighted had a hand in the shaping of Singapore’s history
Learn more about the locations of the key buildings featured in the walks and some information about how they are linked to women in the Singapore Women’s Hall of Fame.

T&Cs:
Patrons accept the risk that in bad weather, the event will be cancelled and acknowledge that tickets will not be exchanged or refunded.

Starting point: Singapore Council of Women’s Organisations 
96 Waterloo Street, 187967
 
Ending point: Armenian Apostolic Church of St. Gregory the Illuminator, 60 Hill St, Singapore 179366
Items.Artist: SCWO - Singapore Council of Women's Organisations

Items.Title: #SGNIGHTFEST by Pan-United
Items.Content:
Over 7-metres long, the #SGNIGHTFEST art installation comprises 3D-printed concrete letters specially created by homegrown concrete company Pan-United. Made with sustainable low-carbon recycled raw materials, each giant letter stacks up to 18 layers of concrete weighing at least 60 kilogrammes. The minimalist clean white concrete in daylight transforms into an exuberantly colourful delight to enjoy after dusk against the architecture of the National Museum of Singapore. Pan-United is a supporter of heritage and the arts, and has collaborated with the National Heritage Board since 2017. #SGNIGHTFEST is Pan-United’s second installation at the Singapore Night Festival.

Come pose with the illuminated giant concrete letters, and snap a photo with your friends and family!
 
About Pan-United
Pan-United Corporation is an Asia-based technology company catalysing change in the concrete and logistics space. A global leader in sustainable concrete technology, it takes pride in making concrete greener and stronger to decarbonise cities. Pan-United creates solutions continually to lower the embodied carbon footprint of concrete and ensure a safer world for future generations.

Items.Title: SG Night Fest Food Tour by Let’s Go Tour
Items.Content:
The Singapore Night Festival (SNF) 2022 returns after a 2-year hiatus, with new interactive art experiences that will be illuminating the bustling Bras Basah.Bugis (BBB) precinct! An exciting line-up of arts, heritage and cultural experiences will take place over two weekends this August 2022.

In this exciting collaboration with SNF, we present to you this curated Night Food Tour to elevate the festival experience. Take a leisure stroll with our expert guides, admire some art installations and eat your way through the Bras Basah.Bugis (BBB) precinct. Discover more about the history of this area, the heritage of the local dishes and the stories behind each dish.

It will be a feast for your tummy and eyes on the SG Night Fest Food Tour! Come join us!

Meeting Point: Albert Food Centre

Rain Policy
This is a rain or shine event, unless there is a thunderstorm. Tours will continue to be conducted with umbrellas or ponchos under drizzling or light rain conditions. Tours will be rescheduled under thunderstorms or heavy rain conditions. Rescheduling is done via the discretion of the guide.

Cancellation Policy (via Credit Card)
Cancellations can only be done 48 hours prior to the tour.
Guests will be refunded 100% via credit card.
Items.Admission: S$35 for picnic or S$50 for dine-in

Items.Title: Singapore Night Festival @ St Joseph's Church
Items.Content:
Immerse yourself in the beauty of this Historical Neo-Gothic Architectural Church and learn about the rich history of the community that dates as far back beyond 1825.

Click here to register for the Guided Tour on the History & Heritage of St. Joseph’s Church.

Tour Dates: August 19, 20, 26, and 27
Tour Timings: 7:40 PM, 8:00 PM, 8:40 PM, 9:00 PM, 9:40 PM, 10:00 PM,

Be creative and fun as you snap memories at our photobooth, or offer your prayer at the Miracle Garden to brighten up the future. Finally, you can chill out with a drink and taste some of our Portuguese Delights with your friends. 

Don't forget to catch these performances happening at the church!

Performances Details

7.30pm - The Sacred Heart Choir
9.20pm - The Sacred Heart Choir

Saturday 27th August
7.30pm - The Sacred Heart Choir
8.20pm- Corrinne May sings Hymns and Sacred Music
8.50pm - Jennifer Tee & Friends

Venue:
St. Joseph's Church (Victoria Street),
143 Victoria St, Singapore 188020

Operating Hours: 7pm to 11.00pm
Church Closed at 11pm

Items.Title: SOTA’s Pop/Jazz Band + Pocket Pugs
Items.Content: If your idea of a perfect evening involves rocking out to your favourite songs from the 80s, 90s and recent chart toppers, come on down for 2 charged sets of music presented by SOTA’s very own Pop/Jazz band and Pocket Pugs at the SOTA Steps! They will be sharing their take on hit tunes and present several jazz numbers along the way, so be ready for a groovy evening!

Venue.Value: SOTA Steps School of the Arts (SOTA),  1 Zubir Said Dr, Singapore 227968

Items.Artist: Pocket Pugs and SOTA POP/Jazz Band

Items.Title: Sing A Cappella!
Items.Content:
A programme held in-conjuction with the Singapore Night Festival, The A Cappella Society is happy to offer a free sampler in contemporary harmony singing with you!

Explore the art of contemporary a cappella singing with this bite-sized introduction and get to know us!

In this workshop you will explore basic vocal technique, canon singing, harmony singing and some improvisation.

We have created a step by step, expansion approach to helping you get immersed into the art of harmony singing without feeling overwhelmed.

The workshop will be conducted by our friendly and approachable Artistic Director, Angelina Choo and you will have an enjoyable time. We can't wait to meet you!

Venue:
The A Cappella Society @ 261 Waterloo Street #02-24

Items.Title: Pickle Party (SNF Edition)
Items.Content:
FEEL THE BRINE~~ Enjoy a multisensory evening of music, pickles, and good vibes with a special edition of Practice Tuckshop’s Pickle Party!

Learn how to transform “ugly” rescued produce into delicious pickles as you harness your inner domestic god(dess) — no cooking experience required. And once the washing, chopping and pickling are done, bring your yummy goodies home to enjoy. It’s an outdoor communal pickling experience unlike any other!

Part of Pickle Party also includes a multimedia installation at 54 Waterloo Street which uses live footage from the pickling process to transform your assumptions about the labour of cooking.

***
This event is by registration only. Registration fee is inclusive of pickling materials and one cup of cold tea. Access to the installation is free.

Items.Title: Make A Good Impression! Stamp Printing Workshop
Items.Content:
This fun and easy activity is a perfect introduction to basic printmaking. Pre-carved rubber printing blocks in a variety of cultural-inspired motifs will be provided. Participants will be guided on how to ink the blocks with different colour stamp pads and print the designs on blank cards. They can mix and match the motifs as they please.

This activity is suitable for all ages.

Venue
Stamford Arts Centre, #01-04

This programme is organised by Arts House Limited as part of “A Date with Tradition”, a festival held in conjunction with the Singapore Night Festival.

Items.Title: Open Studio: Head, Hand & Heart – The Everyday Art of Traditional Crafts
Items.Content:
An early interest in making things by hand, a career in visual arts industry, a love for fashion as wearable art and a decade of fieldwork explorations in regional indigenous crafts - all these have evolved to the current creative work seen in Sau Fen’s studio today.

Take a peek into the studio and learn how her journey of wanting to make hats as artworks led to a humbling journey into the worlds of traditional crafts artisans. The Open Studio would showcase a unique setup of tools from various craft traditions, a diverse collection of materials, works-in-progress and finished creations.

Venue
Stamford Arts Centre, #02-02

This programme is organised by Arts House Limited as part of “A Date with Tradition”, a festival held in conjunction with the Singapore Night Festival.
Items.ImageAlt: [Open Studio] Head, Hand & Heart - The Everyday Art of Traditional Crafts by Chee Sau Fen

Items.Title: Chinese Calligraphy 书法
Items.Content:
Come experience the rich culture and art of Chinese calligraphy, the stylised artistic writing of Chinese characters which is appreciated as a unique visual art form today.

Learn about the ‘scholar’s four jewels’ and see how they come together to create pieces of masterful works. From displays to demonstrations of practised calligraphy works, you are invited to immerse into an enriching Chinese calligraphy appreciation experience with the oldest calligraphy society in the nation.

书法艺术拥有深层的文化美学，经过两千多年的演变与发展，如今已是自成一格的视觉艺术，为世人所欣赏。欢迎您来体验书法艺术的美妙，了解书法中所谓的 ”文房四宝”，只需一只笔、一张纸、一碟墨，就能创造出一幅幅优秀的书法作品。您也将有机会欣赏新加坡书法家协会成员展示的作品。

This activity is conducted in Mandarin and English.

Venue
Stamford Arts Centre, #01-01

This programme is organised by Arts House Limited as part of “A Date with Tradition”, a festival held in conjunction with the Singapore Night Festival.
Items.Artist: Chinese Calligraphy Society of Singapore新加坡书法家协会

Items.Title: Percussive Rhythms
Items.Content:
Ding Yi Music Company will present a variety of repertoires in different styles and instrumentation, featuring the versatility of percussion instruments from east to west. Led by percussion musicians Low Yik Hang, Cheong Kah Yiong and sheng musician Soh Swee Kiat, you will get a chance to play percussion together with them and create rhythmic grooves in this energetic and engaging session.

Musicians
Percussion: Low Yik Hang, Cheong Kah Yiong
Sheng: Soh Swee Kiat

Venue
Stamford Arts Centre, #02-06

This programme is organised by Arts House Limited as part of “A Date with Tradition”, a festival held in conjunction with the Singapore Night Festival.

Items.Title: Sulam Circle
Items.Content:
A needle, a thread, a stitch. Together we sew and mend, giving life to fragments of materials making it whole and adding touches of colours of life.

The stitches of sulam circle are about forging bonds with one another among family, friends or sewers, relishing the rich traditions of hand sewn embroidery motifs of the Peranakan kebayas.

Come pop by to learn more about embroidery, see the demonstration of fine machine work and join us in the sulam circle for some stitching fun!

This activity will be conducted in English and Mandarin. Adult supervision is required for participants aged 13 years and below.

Venue
Stamford Arts Centre, #03-04

This programme is organised by Arts House Limited as part of “A Date with Tradition”, a festival held in conjunction with the Singapore Night Festival.

Items.Title: The Art of Sulam
Items.Content:
Heath Yeo will share and demonstrate the process of creating sulam designs using the manual treadle sewing machine. This unique way of embroidering is typically created by the embroiderer manually paddling the sewing machine with his or her feet while skilfully manoeuvring a tightly hooped fabric under the needle to create a design. Since the sewing machine has only one needle, the embroiderer often pauses to re-thread the machine manually for every colour that is used in a multi-coloured design such as a phoenix or a flower.

Venue
Stamford Arts Centre, #03-04

This programme is organised by Arts House Limited as part of “A Date with Tradition”, a festival held in conjunction with the Singapore Night Festival.
Items.ImageAlt: The Art of Sulam by Heath Yeo

Items.Title: Illuminate
Items.Content:
This programme will share about the basic forms of Chinese dance and bring you into the intricacies of Chinese classical and ethnic folk dance. Come and immerse yourself in a lively and melodious atmosphere that will tug at your heartstrings!

Dancers: Li Ruimin, Wang Wenbo, Wong Zhuo Qin, Tee Qiao Li

Venue
Stamford Arts Centre, #02-01 

This programme is organised by Arts House Limited as part of “A Date with Tradition”, a festival held in conjunction with the Singapore Night Festival.

Items.Title: Folk Sounds
Items.Content:
Join Nanyang Collective in a night where we bring you through a journey of our different ethnic folk songs and tunes. Our musicians will introduce to you their amazing instruments and mesmerise you with their music. Led by Producer Sherman Lee and conducted by Wong De Li Dedric.

Registration on-site required.

Items.Title: Mass Delay
Items.Content:
Mass Delay is a reimagined performance from Norhaizad Adam’s solo work ‘Delay’. In these four iterations, performers will be accessing and negotiating the strength of Pressure-Sensitive Adhesives (PSA) accompanied by real-time sonic responses from four different sound artists.

This work is a journey of self-assessment. It takes the form of Tumpang Lalu (Excuse me), the shrinking of the body that Malay folks execute to walk in front of someone. It is also about un-bodying the self, an apologetic self-consciousness of the space one takes up in the world.

Tumpang lalu is a prominent gesture that guides Malay dancers across the performance space as they encounter one another, inscribing Malay dance as a codified system of social protocols. As a model for the community, the Malay dancer is conditioned by the value of Budi which is central to Malay culture and philosophy. Budi refers to rationality, intelligence and courtesy.

Show 2: 9pm – 9.30pm (with Luqman Hakim)

Items.Title: An Evening with Shadows
Items.Content:
Experience and appreciate the different ways of playing shadow puppetry, with a special display of traditional shadow puppets including Sun Wukong, the Monkey King from Chinese classic “Journey to the West”, and Prince Rama from Indian epic “Ramayana”, and more!

This activity is suitable for all ages. Adult supervision is required for participants aged 12 years and below.

Venue
Stamford Arts Centre, #02-05

This programme is organised by Arts House Limited as part of “A Date with Tradition”, a festival held in conjunction with the Singapore Night Festival.

Items.Title: A Close-up Session with Century Old Puppet Troupe
Items.Content:
This is a rare chance to get up close with Singapore’s century old Hainanese puppet troupe San Chun Long, as the troupe members share their journey of performing rod puppetry shows at various countries over the years, and how the traditional art form has been passed from generation to generation. You will also get to see the delicate movements of the puppets skilfully executed by the puppeteers.

新加坡海南木偶戏班可谓新马一带硕果仅存的木偶戏班，具有百年历史，在全盛时期一年有超过百场演出，也曾深受广大民众的喜爱。在这项活动中，您可以与三春隆木偶戏班的木偶师做近距离的接触，听听他们述说过去到各地演出的经历，还有如何操作杖头木偶。

This programme is conducted in Mandarin and English.

Venue
Stamford Arts Centre, #03-02

This programme is organised by Arts House Limited as part of “A Date with Tradition”, a festival held in conjunction with the Singapore Night Festival.
Items.Artist: San Chun Long Hainanese Puppet Troupe 三春隆海南木偶戏班

Items.Title: Open Studio: Century Old Hainanese Rod Puppets
Items.Content:
Be mesmerised by the antique rod puppets and stage belonging to Singapore’s oldest Hainanese puppet troupe, San Chun Long. These puppets have withstood the test of time as they travelled to various parts of Nanyang (present Southeast Asia) for the past hundred years. Come over to interact with the friendly puppeteers and you may stand a chance to go up close with these unique rod puppets!

新加坡海南木偶戏班三春隆将展示古色古香、色彩斑斓的杖头木偶及戏台。这些杖头木偶在过去百年来，曾随着木偶戏班到南洋（今日东南亚）各地演出。这次的活动，您将有机会与三春隆的木偶师进行交流并亲身接触这些独特的木偶！

Venue
Stamford Arts Centre, #03-02

This programme is organised by Arts House Limited as part of “A Date with Tradition”, a festival held in conjunction with the Singapore Night Festival.
Items.Artist: San Chun Long Hainanese Puppet Troupe 三春隆海南木偶戏班

Items.Title: Indian Rainbow
Items.Content:
This brief presentation is a cursory glimpse into the vast Indian Rainbow of Performing Arts, where we hope to ignite the imagination of our audience through lucid explanations with full bodied performances and also for the audience to have an opportunity to tell a story purely through hand gestures, in an interactive session at the end.

We begin with a dance on the elephant-headed God Ganesha, believed to be the remover of all obstacles. Hence performed at the beginning of a programme to ensure its success.

One of the other colours of the spectrum is about a 13th Century Queen, who not only brought prosperity to her kingdom, but was a great patron of the arts. Her reign involved numerous wars she had to fight to protect her people.

Creative Team
Choreographer: Shantha Ratii
Dancers: Dr Krishnan Unni A S & Manjeera Pariti
Narrator: Shantha Ratii
Costume re-design: Shantha Ratii
Make-up artist: Bhamah Ramdas

Stamford Arts Centre, #02-01

This programme is organised by Arts House Limited as part of “A Date with Tradition”, a festival held in conjunction with the Singapore Night Festival.

Items.Title: Singa Rangoli Workshop
Items.Content:
Join Singa Rangoli to collaboratively create a vibrant larger-than-life rangoli on the floor of Stamford Arts Centre in this creative participatory activity. Singa Rangoli means Singapore-Rangoli. In this activity, new materials will be used, other than the usual colour powder. Experience and learn about rangoli, of which the designs are usually inspired by nature, and contribute your share to a growing piece of rangoli art.

Venue
Stamford Arts Centre, #01-05

This programme is organised by Arts House Limited as part of “A Date with Tradition”, a festival held in conjunction with the Singapore Night Festival.

Items.Title: Singapore Rhapsodies
Items.Content:
SwaRhythm Ensemble will present five pieces of music inspired by our rich cultures.

The first piece, ‘Dance of Nature’, is a celebration of how nature moves with music and music comes from nature. We then move to ‘Flame of the Mystic’, a tribute to the Sufi compositions of Amir Khusrau and Baba Hazrat with the oud, a traditional Malay instrument, taking the lead.

‘Dancing Dragon, Rising Phoenix’ takes us to China as the band explores the synergies between Indian ragas and traditional Chinese melodies of the erhu. ‘Singapore Rain’ is then played in raag Malhar, or the rain raag, as a tribute to the monsoons.

We conclude with ‘Swarhythm Blues’, a composition heavily influenced by jazz and blues and is set to raag Jhog.

All in all, this programme is about how all the cultures on our island comes together in celebration of music, nature, and the things that unite us.

Note: Registration on-site required. Not all pieces will be performed at each session.

Items.Title: Ark Music Live Session
Items.Content:
Over the years, The Ark has transformed from physical live performances to virtual live performances at Stamford Arts Centre. As part of “A Date with Tradition”, The Ark’s in-house singers will present, through live streaming, 3 hours of non-stop Mandarin pop songs, from xinyao (Singapore songs) to the latest hits. Come and see how live streaming of an acoustic performance is like behind the scenes, or simply enjoy The Ark’s live music at the below platforms. 

随着时间的推移，木船从以往的现场演唱方式，进展到如今的线上直播方式，继续分享音乐的美好。这次活动，他们将通过三小时不间断的直播，呈献多首动听的华语流行歌曲，包括新谣以及最新热门歌曲。现场的朋友可以看看木船歌手进行线上直播的幕后情景，了解制作直播节目的过程。您也可以点击以下链接观赏木船的线上直播。

Items.Title: Discover the Charm of Chinese Opera 戏曲赏析会
Items.Content:
Through the appreciation of traditional Chinese operas, the public will gain better understanding of the performance characteristics and experience its artistic charm. With fun and lively interactions, the public will acquire knowledge of traditional arts and have a deeper understanding of traditional Chinese cultural and educational values. This will in turn promote the inheritance and dissemination of traditional arts in Singapore.

Presented by Cai Bixia
Demonstration by Zhang Manxi

通过戏曲知识赏析，让公众了解传统戏曲行当的表演特点，亲身感受戏曲表演的艺术魅力，并通过生动有趣的互动，近距离的接触与学习传统艺术，更深入的了解华族传统文化教育价值观，从而有效推动我国传统艺术的传承与传播工作。

主讲：蔡碧霞
示范：张曼熙

This programme will be conducted in Mandarin with English interpretation.

Stamford Arts Centre, #03-05

Items.Artist: Traditional Arts Centre (Singapore)   新加坡传统艺术中心

Items.Title: Steps (2022) by Victoria Hertel
Items.Content:
As nightfall approaches, Steps (2022) powers up to illuminate the National Museum of Singapore’s glass staircase in a welcoming white glow. The motion-responsive installation is activated by the presence and movement of visitors to materialise vibrant color changes, inviting visitors to experience the energetic bond between themselves and their surrounding space. In line with the festival’s theme “Rebirth”, the artist creates an ephemeral, light-immersed space that invites interaction along the Museum’s colonial facade. The installation’s participatory design employs light as a bridging element to reconnect visitors with their spatial environment and the traces they create within it.

 

*A version of Steps was previously presented at Singapore Art Week 2022.

  

About Victoria Hertel

Victoria Hertel is a German-Venezuelan artist whose practice merges site-specific painting and installation to create immersive experiences. Exploring the entanglement of the body, materiality and space, her work focuses on constructing distilled sensory encounters to heighten and alter our awareness of our surroundings. Hertel has been awarded the Chan-Davies Art Prize for academic excellence in her Master of Arts research and practice of Trace as energy in materialities. Her work has been exhibited in solo shows, group exhibitions as well as residencies in Germany, Spain, Austria, Poland, China, Taiwan and Singapore.

Items.Title: Stories from Forbidden Hill by Maxin10sity
Items.Content:
Experience a visual narrative of Singapore’s mythical origins and history dating back to the 14th century with Stories from Forbidden Hill. Let the amalgamation of ancient wall murals, nature, and national treasures spark wonder as you immerse in the beauty of the past against the backdrop of the National Museum of Singapore. The projection showcase presents significant historical locations such as the wall carvings and royal bath at Fort Canning Park, as well as the legend of Badang, of whom the earliest record can be found in the Sejarah Melayu, an important record of Malay history.

 

About Maxin10sity

Maxin10sity is a Hungarian projection mapping production studio established in 2014 by multi-award winning 3D mapping artists László Czigány and Andras Sass alongside Tamás Vaspöri. The company specialises in building mapping, indoor mapping, car mapping and other functions, and has participated in light festivals such as the Berlin Light Festivals 2015 - 2017, the Audi Late Light Show 2017, the LUMA Projection Arts Festival in Binghamton, NYC, and more. Their work also includes a permanent projection for the famous Oriental Pearl Tower in Shanghai and a monumental, record-breaking projection mapping for the Facade of the Parliament of Romania.

Items.Title: TERRARIUM by Aux Media Group, Binary Style, PAPERSYNTHESIS and BIOS_ Living NFTs
Items.Content:
TERRARIUM imagines a hybridised reality that ponders future possibilities for nature and how technology could blur the lines between what’s living and what’s truly alive.

Step into an immersive garden landscape dreamt up by AUX Media Group in collaboration with lifestyle brand Binary Style, who is also launching a special Bras Basah.Bugis precinct design commission and merchandise; have a picnic amidst the gorgeous paper flora creations by PAPERSYNTHESIS; and examine how game engines and 3D modelling allow nature to thrive in the digital realm through a dynamic and interactive display by BIOS: Living NFTs, where you can help a digital garden grow. Living, not alive, these plants are inherently digital, yet also responsive inhabitants of the virtual and physical realms.

This artwork is co-presented by the National Heritage Board (NHB), the DesignSingapore Council and the National Design Centre as part of Singapore Night Festival.

About the artists
AUX Media Group evolved from a traditional events company to a leader in extended reality, using technology to create immersive storytelling. SERIAL CO_ is the creative technology studio behind BIOS: Living NFTS, that aims to connect the physical world with the Metaverse.

Binary Style is a homegrown design atelier that is helmed by twin sisters Santhi and Sari Tunas. Formerly trained as architects, the sisters explore architecture, nature and heritage as inspirations for their multi-media design creation.

PAPERSYNTHESIS is a paper floral studio established by Singapore-based paper artist, Mabel Low in 2020. Mabel started experimenting with making paper plants as a more durable option after a slew of houseplant casualties. The studio mainly designs and crafts florals and foliages from card-stock papers. All papers used are carefully selected based on their unique textures, colours and properties. All PAPERSYNTHESIS products are designed and handcrafted in Singapore.

BIOS: Living NFTs is a collectible NFT art project inspired by variegated plant collecting and the immortalisation of virtual plants on the blockchain. The work is created as a randomly generated collectible NFT that takes the form of variegated plants produced from a combination of 3D modelling, machine learning algorithms and procedural programming to produce 1024 one-of-a-kind 3D plants that can be viewed, owned, traded and will grow from a seed to a mature plant on the blockchain.
Items.ImageAlt: TERRARIUM by Aux Media Group, Binary Style, PAPERSYNTHESIS and BIOS_ Living NFTs
Items.Artist: Aux Media Group, Binary Style, PAPERSYNTHESIS and SERIAL CO_

Items.Title: The Melting Pot by Adeline Tan and Benedict Teo
Items.Content:
The Melting Pot is an ode to the multiracial communities of Chinese, Peranakans, Eurasians, Jews, Malays, Indians, Sikhs, Japanese, Armenian, Europeans, and others who lived in close proximity at the Bras Basah.Bugis precinct from the 19th century to the 1930s. The multifaceted visual language of the different cultures in the precinct is reflected through the unique design elements from fabric, architecture and street scenes. As a tribute to this part of history, the animation features a kaleidoscope of patterns associated with the different ethnic groups merging and transiting into one another.

About Adeline Tan
Adeline Tan (aka mightyellow) is an illustrator and visual artist based in Singapore. Taking inspiration from personal experiences, the environment and popular culture, Adeline imagines alternate realities to current situations. Adeline has worked on notable projects with Adidas, Disney and Facebook. She is currently represented by Mulan Gallery, Singapore.

About Benedict Teo
Benedict Teo is the co-founder of Metamo Industries, a team that develops immersive audio-visual experiences that transcend traditional media capabilities. An award-winning DJ and Artiste Booker formerly known by his stage name “Zushan”, Benedict continues his music endeavours through music production and performing under his artiste projects, “Owe Money Pay Money — O$P$” and “Benedict & Palmer”. He is also currently the Music Curator for Ritual Gym.
Items.ImageAlt: The Melting Pot by Adeline Tan and Benedict Teo

Items.Title: The Mind Cafe: What Do You Meme Contest x Singapore Night Festival 2022
Items.Content: Board games stimulate mental well-being, as it gets people thinking and strategising. It also sparks conversations and brings people together. Visit The Mind Cafe @ 30 Prinsep Street from 19th to 27th Aug and stand a chance to win S$1,000 worth of prizes when you take part in the What Do You Meme Contest x Singapore Night Festival 2022!

Items.Title: Light Up - The Peranakan Museum
Items.Content:
Peranakan Museum is coming back with a bang in 2023! Meanwhile, catch our façade light up and join in the festivities on Armenian Street.

The Peranakan Museum, 39 Armenian St, Singapore 179941

Items.Title: The Cage @ Throttle Up (Drone Workshop)
Items.Content:
The Cage by ThrottleUp is coming to Bugis+ in conjunction with Singapore Night Festival. Signup for a drone try-out with our pilot instructors and fly inside The Cage, a state-of-the-art LED drone arena. You can also put on the FPV goggles and hop on for a joyride with our pro-pilots. ThrottleUp with us!

About ThrottleUp
ThrottleUp Creation specialises in FPV (first person view) Drone Cinematography, Drone Flying Academy, Space Activation and other creative projects with drone technologies and innovations.
We create new perspectives through FPV content creation, promote drone flying with our workshop programs, and craft new experiences by bringing drone flying to new spaces.

Venue
Bugis+, Bugis Plaza (Outside J.Co)

Items.Title: Through Worlds by Jo Ho and Intriguant
Items.Content:
Through Worlds is an imagination of the endless possibilities that emerging technologies can provide us, which includes traveling through parallel worlds that simultaneously exist with our current physical one. Viewers will travel through a series of virtual environments with an audio narration of multiple perspectives within the history and hypothetical, imagined future of Chijmes and the area around it, by immersing themselves in alternate environments that connects the present to other places and time through the old school building, Chijmes in 2088 or a virtual public space. These scenes are tied together by a common trajectory: moving forward on a path through historical and future worlds.

About Jo Ho
Jo Ho is an artist working with digital and physical spaces that question the role of agency and creation of meaning and value in our increasingly automated world, where views of "machine as tool" and "machine as creator" are being challenged. Her recent work explores perceptions of digital media today and attempts to reveal the tangibility beneath digital works in today’s world of rapid content production. Her recent work attempts to question the misconception that digital assets are immaterial, pushing the idea of what she calls “digital corporeality” by presenting digital works in alternative formats.

About Intriguant
Intriguant is a Singapore-based Electronic Music Producer / Sound Designer / DJ. Inspired by the human perception of environment and spaces, he blends textural sounds, rhythms, backed with syncopated beats, in turn fusing the physical with the spiritual. With music and sound design as his foundation, he delves into other mediums such as art installations, theatre, and etc.
Items.ImageAlt: Through Worlds by Jo Ho and Intriguant

Items.Title: tobyato bird pitstop by tobyato
Items.Content:
Inspired by the William Farquhar collection of drawings, tobyato bird pitstop is an artistic, inflatable representation of birds taking a breather in Fort Canning Park. Walk along the path and spot the rare sightings of birds resting within the lush greenery.

The collection of inflatable birds features migratory species recently spotted in the vicinity, such as the Grey and Purple Herons, the Violet Cuckoo and the White-rumped Shama. The larger-than-life artworks aim to highlight Singapore’s biodiversity and the myriad of bird species that often goes unnoticed within our small island nation. Learning from these birds taking pit stops to rest on their own migratory journeys, tobyato bird pitstop reminds us to slow down and rejuvenate ourselves in nature as well.

About tobyato
tobyato is an illustrator and visual artist over many mediums. Ranging from sprawling murals to brand collaborations, his artworks are often bold, striking and inspired by traditional Chinese motifs and playful influences that reflect both his own heritage and personality. From painting the grounds of iconic Somerset skate park to the side of shophouses in Tanjong Pagar, tobyato endeavours to continue to make art more accessible in Singapore. As a lover of street culture, he worked with brands such as G-SHOCK, Shake Shack, Levi’s, and ASICS among others, steadily building a body of work that exemplifies artist brand collaborations.

Items.Title: Trash Terrarium
Items.Content:
Reimagine the possibilities of waste!

Presented by The Idea Co and Miniwiz, witness how technology can turn trash into treasure at TRASHLAB during the Singapore Night Festival, and take home your very own sustainable terrarium or ornament bowl.

A public collection drive of clean bottle caps will also be run during the festival, to create new uses for these materials and build a truly circular economy.

Reef Rescue, a game that educates on issues around marine pollution, will also be available for demo and purchase.

Demonstration: Free
• $38 - $68 for sustainable terrariums and ornament bowls
• $4- $6 for drinks, as part of a collection drive for clean bottle caps during SNF
• $18 for Reef Rescue game on marine plastic pollution

Any enquiries: hello@theideaco.org

Venue.Value: TRASHLAB at National Design Centre (in front of Atrium)

Items.Title: Tunnel Graffiti by Lynette Quek
Items.Content:
Like a portal into another dimension, Tunnel Graffiti plays on history within a contemporary setting, taking inspiration from street art, cyberpunk and hieroglyphics. The artwork showcases imagery unique to the precinct, redefining perceptions of graffiti in Singapore’s tucked-away tunnels and streetscapes. In response to the Fort Canning Mural Wall, the graphics reimagine the motifs of life in old Singapura captured on the stone reliefs using contemporary expressions. This serves to catapult heritage beyond the definitions of modernity, providing a pathway to revisit Fort Canning’s history within an augmented environment. Activated by sounds captured in the space, the interactive artwork serves up a new experience within a familiar setting. Visitors are essential in activating the work, highlighting how human activities catalyse changes to the environment.

About Lynette Quek
Lynette Quek is an audiovisual maker from Singapore. Emerging from a music and audio technology background, Quek nurtured an interest in multi-disciplinary arts, combining audio and visual elements in her work. Her work examines the synchronisation and interaction within audiovisuality, varying across the mediums of video, performance, sculpture, electronics, and more. She also explores the integration of technology and art by examining the relationships between digital and physical elements. Utilising a variety of tools and mediums, she explores these possibilities made through or countered by technology. Quek has presented her works in Singapore, Taiwan, and across the United Kingdom, Europe, and Central America.

 

Tunnel Graffiti is fabricated by GX Innovate and assembled together with Lim Wen Ling and Daiso One.

Items.Title: Twinkle into the Night - Wings & Terrarium Craft Buffet
Items.Content:
Want a little teaser of what Children’s Museum Singapore has to offer when they open their doors in December? Drop by their craft booth along Armenian Street! Light up your night with DIY butterfly wings or terrariums. Pssst…they both twinkle in the night!

Follow Children’s Museum Singapore on Facebook @Ilovecmsg on Instagram for latest updates.

Items.Title: Under My Tree Roof by Chloë Manasseh
Items.Content:
Right at home amidst the flora and fauna of Fort Canning Park, Under My Tree Roof curves around the park’s iconic spiral staircase and beckons visitors to experience the dichotomy between the mural’s sheer scale and the intricacy of the constructed spaces it sits in as they transit through. The interpretative artwork, which features local elements such as wild spice flowers, heritage trees and native birds, stimulates deep reflection on the perceptions of identity and rootedness within a landscape. In its exploration of nature, Under My Tree Roof also posits the idea that perhaps a true wilderness can no longer exist against the backdrop of the modern landscape and in the digital era. Situated under the Yellow Rain Tree, the spiral pathway will provide a place of respite from day to night as the colourful botanical forms come to life in the dark.

About Chloë Manasseh
Chloë Manasseh is a British-Israeli artist residing in Singapore. Working with paint, print, video and installation pieces, her practice explores the fragility of vision and our intrinsic attachment to landscapes which underpins our sense of identity. Her work is featured in several public and private collections around the world, including The Raffles Hotel in Singapore, and has been exhibited across the UK, USA, Singapore, Israel and Italy.

Under My Tree Roof is photographed and edited by Nasrul Sunny.
Items.ImageAlt: Under My Tree Roof by Chloë Manasseh

Items.Title: VANS Instore Workshop
Items.Content:
Experience the process of customising your very own Vans at Vans Bugis Junction this Singapore Night festival!

How to register: Indicate interest / register at VANS IG page @vans.sg

Items.Title: Voyage
Items.Content:
This digital installation brings to life the botanical and zoological species depicted in the National Museum of Singapore’s William Farquhar Collection of Natural History Drawings. Join us on a ‘voyage’ to discover the plants and animals of the Southeast Asian natural world, before continuing the journey to the museum’s Story of the Forest installation.

Duration: 4 min 20 sec

National Museum of Singapore Glass Atrium, Level 2
Items.Time: 19 and 20 Aug: 5pm – 12am 26 and 27 Aug: 2pm – 4pm, 5pm – 12am On other days: 2pm – 6pm

Items.Title: We Can No Longer Be Strangers After This by Perception3
Items.Content:
In response to the festival theme of ‘Rebirth’, We can no longer be strangers after this invites us to reflect on the shifts and changes we have had to adapt to, the lessons we have learned, and what it means to transition to a post-pandemic life. Featuring two sets of texts on reflective panels, placed side by side in the green space, the work is envisioned as a ‘memorial’ of this moment in time:

WE CAN NO LONGER BE STRANGERS AFTER THIS
WE ARE BOUND IN THIS DREAM TOGETHER

Encouraging viewers to think about their shared and interconnected experiences, the work is a poetic invitation to reflect critically on our collective narratives of resilience, solidarity and transformation as we contemplate what lies ahead - the uncertainties that persist, what we would need to do, and how we might need or rely on each other.

Venue
Grass Patch Near Banyan Tree at National Museum Singapore

About the Perception3
Perception3 is an interdisciplinary art duo founded in 2007 by artist and writer Regina De Rozario and design practitioner Seah Sze Yunn. Their collaborative practice focuses on exploring the notions of loss and memory in the wake of Singapore’s transformation of its city spaces. Through their work, they point to the relationships encountered between the self and city, and how narratives and art may play a role in shaping what is to be forgotten and remembered. Their works are expressed primarily through text, photography, digital video, and site specific installation, and have been collected and showcased in Singapore and Internationally.
